rename.from: [BUG] Prophet wrapper internally changing X (exogenous data)
rename.to: [BUG] Prophet wrapper internally changing argument X (exogenous data)

body:
@IlyasMoutawwakil, are you positive that this is a *side effect* on the argument `X`?
That is, is the object `X`, after passing to the prophet estimator, differenf from when passed?

I would be surprised.
Why was this not captured by `test_all_estimators/test_methods_have_no_side_effects`?

ah, I can answer this myself: `_make_args` creates no `X` for forecasting.

So the test would not detect a side effect in `X`.

issue.title: [ENH] `test_methods_have_no_side_effects` should test for side effects in all key arguments

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
See #1673.

The prophet wrapper has side effects on `X`.

This was not discovered by `test_all_estimators/test_methods_have_no_side_effects` since its key dependency `_make_args`, which creates default arguments, does not create non-trivial `X` (this is set to `None`).

`_make_args` should be modified that all arguments of critical functions are properly tested for side effects.

body:
I've turned the lack of test coverage into an issue here:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1674

I'm pretty positive, here I created X_train dataframe with no `ds` column and was added to it after the call to `fit`.

https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1TtZJMLKIC2jJUPmWanbBAn9GobtCPJEZ?usp=sharing
Yes, I've observed the same before but forgot to raise the issue. Thanks for raising it now @IlyasMoutawwakil!
so basically we just have to add `X = X.copy()`? Is so, this should probably happen in the base class
we also need to check whether the case that `X` *already* has a column named `ds` is covered properly.

> so basically we just have to add X = X.copy()? 

I think that would work, first thing in `_fit` and `_predict`.
Seems a simple fix, hence good first issue.
@kejsitake offered to work on this, thanks!

issue.title: Fixes prophet bug concerning the internal change of exogenous X

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1673

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

- Reproduced the error described in  https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1673
- Creates a copy of X in _Prophet_Adapter before changes are made to it.
- Verified that the code snippet int he issue document a bug doesn't throw the error after this change.
- Checks if X contained a column ds were already implemented in _merge_X, so I didn't implement a new one

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No
<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->



<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body:
I think neither - it is the prophet class that needs to be fixed.
None of the forecasters should behave differently with a column `ds` or without.
None of the forecasters should change argument `X` being passed to them.

So there are two things to fix:
* high-priority, the side effect of the prophet forecaster on `X` - the argument should not be modified
* lower-priority, writing a test that would catch this (this is issue #1674)
